ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the book This Shoe Needs a Foot and learned about how a shoe got help to find the right foot that would fit inside of it.
In this activity, we will look at pictures of different shoes and guess who is wearing these shoes.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Sort Give the picture card to a child to organize with the other cards so they appear in order from the smallest shoes to the largest shoes.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card. Keep asking children to sort the photos from the smallest shoes to the largest.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-card_run-in_hed: Talk About Sizes of Feet and Shoes
ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In This Shoe Needs a Foot, how did the animals measure the shoe? How did that help to find which foot fit in the shoe? Some of the animals’ feet were small and some were big. Some were long and some were short. Let’s talk about the different feet we saw in the pictures. Then we will organize the other cards from the smallest shoes to the biggest shoes.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: For children who are having a hard time visualizing who is wearing the shoes in the picture cards, have them describe what they see in the picture. Ask if they have seen shoes like these? If so, who was wearing the shoes?
Invite children to name different types of shoes. What kinds of shoes do they wear for playing outside? Do they wear shoes to go to bed? What would they wear on their feet for skating on ice?

Research shows that children who grow up speaking more than one language have a cognitive advantage. They learn flexible thinking at a young age. They learn that the labels assigned to different objects, such as the word for shoe, are arbitrary, and that any given object can be assigned more than one label.

Consider having children take off one of their shoes and have them line the shoes up according to size in an empty space. Have them measure the shoes with a ruler and see how many different sizes there are. Share children’s foot size with them by writing the number on a piece of paper. Then show children how shoes have different numbers to represent different sizes.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we revisited the book This Shoe Needs a Foot and talked about how important it is to ask and answer questions.
You ask and answer questions when you learn something new or if you are sharing information.
We learned the words alike and different. Let’s revisit the words since they have something to do with the activity we will play today.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Explain the Activity We’re going to look at some pictures of different people and things. We’re going to talk about if we can tell if they are alike or different.
Ask Show one picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

Talk About Asking and Answering Questions Encourage children to ask their own questions about each picture card. Children can ask other questions about what they see in the pictures, such as about the clothes the people are wearing, what they are doing, or what items they see in the pictures.
Begin by discussing each picture card with children. Identify what they see in each picture. Then go back and ask the questions on the back of each card.
Ask children if they can come up with additional questions related to how things are alike and how they are different. Children can compare heights, sizes, etc.

Use these picture cards to help children develop oral language and vocabulary. Encourage children to name as many things as they can in each picture. What do they see? What colors do they see? What shapes? What is happening in each picture? Does anything remind them of something in their own lives? Can they teach the class one word in their home language that describes an object in each picture?
For students who came up with stories about the people in the pictures, ask them to make drawings that show the stories they have made up.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the book This Shoe Needs a Foot and read about animals with long feet and short feet. We also read about how the animals helped the shoe find the right foot by measuring how long or short their feet were.
In this activity, we’ll look at pictures of different things and sort them into two groups:

ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted.ac_teacher-speaking: “Short” for things that are not long

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-talk-emphasis: Point out things in the classroom that are long and short.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Revisit Vocabulary We learned the words alike and different this week. Let’s revisit these words. Use the alike and different Vocabulary Cards.
Ask Show one picture card and ask the questions on the back of the card, offering extra challenge and support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.

Sort Write “long” and “short” on pieces of paper to create column headings for the picture cards. Give the picture cards to a child to line up under the different column headings. Allow each child a turn.
Repeat Continue the activity with the next card.
Talk About Measuring Tools Talk about what children learned by measuring long and short and how they can use a ruler to measure. Explaining why measuring things is important.

Have children describe what they see in each picture. This will help children as they try to identify if something is long or if it is short. Having them talk things through will help them answer the questions.
Challenge children to explain what helped them decide if what they saw was long or short. Have them think about ways they might measure to find out how long or how short something is.

Ask children to measure their hands using a ruler. Ask children to say the number in their home language. Having children use numbers in their home language might help them feel more comfortable talking about measurements.

Helping children focus their attention is a critical learning milestone for preschoolers. You can help children focus their attention through a variety of strategies, including using simple directions and previewing each activity before you begin. Model what to do with each card and check to make sure that all children know what to do.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the poster called I Can Measure and learned how to measure different objects including those that are heavy and light.
We learned the words heavy and light. Let’s revisit those words.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-talk-emphasis: Vocabulary Cards to revisit the words.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, we will look at pictures of different objects. We will sort the pictures into two groups:

ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted.ac_teacher-speaking: Heavy objects that weigh a lot and are hard to carry.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted: Light objects that are easy to carry and do not weigh a lot.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Sort Give the picture card to a child to line up in the “heavy” or “light” group.
Repeat Continue the game using the next picture card.

Talk About Heavy and Light Objects Talk about the weight of different classroom objects with children and how some things are heavier or lighter than other things. Have children sort classroom objects, such as toys or books, from lightest to heaviest.
Before you begin, make sure children understand the meaning of feather. Help children respond in complete sentences by saying the answer in a complete sentence and having children repeat after you.

For the cards that are put in the “heavy” category, ask children to name something they can think of that is heavier than what is on the card. For the “light” cards, ask them to think of something that is lighter.

Have children pantomime carrying heavy objects and light objects. Have children pretend that they are carrying two books, then three books, then four books, and then five books. Have children pretend to be pushing a large couch. Then have children pretend to be pushing a chair across the floor. Which object is heavier?

Young children use all of their senses to observe the world around them. Ask them how they determined whether the picture card showed something heavy. Was their decision based on the size of the object? Are there some big things that are not heavy? Are there some small things that are heavy? Which materials are heavy? Which is heavier, concrete or paper? Wood or cotton?
